ABC of Games

Whether you're looking to become a rock-star game developer or E-sport champion, you must understand how games truly work. Many games share similar concepts which have been broken down into the ABC of Games. Select a lesson below to start the exploration! Follow the Optimal Lesson Plan for the best learning experience.

(hover over lesson to see interactive preview)

A is for Acceleration

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity over time

START LESSON

B is for Bounce

Bounce is the elasticity of an object

START LESSON

C is for Collision

Collision causes objects to hit each other

START LESSON

D is for Drag

Dragging is a way to interact with an object

START LESSON

E is for Experience

Experience is a way to track user progress

START LESSON

F is for Frames

Frames are used to design animations

START LESSON

G is for Gravity

Gravity is the acceleration in the world

START LESSON

H is for Health

Health is a way to track damage to an object

START LESSON

I is for Immovable

Immovable objects create the boundaries of the game

START LESSON

J is for Jump

Jumping is a way to control an object

START LESSON

K is for Kill

Kill refers to destroying objects

START LESSON

L is for Lives

Lives are a way to track how long a game lasts

START LESSON

M is for Movement

Movement provides a way to control an object

START LESSON

N is for Noise

Noise occurs when using sound effects

START LESSON

O is for Obstacles

Obstacles are objects the user must avoid

START LESSON

P is for Platformer

Platformer is a style of game play

START LESSON

Q is for Quests

Quests provide a challenge for users to complete

START LESSON

R is for Runner

Runner is a style of game play

START LESSON

S is for Sprite

Sprites are the objects in the game

START LESSON

T is for Timer

Timers help with periodic events in a game

START LESSON

U is for Upgrading

Upgrading is way to enhance the attributes of an object

START LESSON

V is for Velocity

Velocity is the rate of change of distance over time

START LESSON

W is for Weapon

Weapon is an object used to shoot a projectile

START LESSON

X is for X-axis

X-axis is the location of an object side to side

START LESSON

Y is for Y-axis

Y-axis is the location of an object up and down

START LESSON

Z is for Z-index

Z-index is the layering of objects

START LESSON

Optimal Lesson Plan

Most of the lessons reference one or more other concepts to provide a comprehensive understanding of the topic. Going in alphabetical order is not necessarily the best way to learn all the topics as earlier lessons contain references to future topics. Listed below is the optimal order in which the lessons can be reviewed. Going in the order listed will ensure you have already learned all other topics referenced in a lesson.

S
S is for Sprite
